Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'CustomActions.InsertInternalWebService(Session)' could contain the following variables 'session["INPORT"]'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.
In method 'CustomActions.ProtectServiceConfigFile(string, string, string)', call System.IDisposable.Dispose on object 'service' before all references to it are out of scope.

Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'CustomActions.TestDatabaseIsExist(string, string)' could contain the following variables 'databaseName'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

In method 'CustomActions.UpdateCertificate(Session)', object 'stream' is not disposed along all exception paths. Call System.IDisposable.Dispose on object 'stream' before all references to it are out of scope.

'CustomActions.UpdateCertificate(Session)' rethrows a caught exception and specifies it explicitly as an argument. Use 'throw' without an argument instead, in order to preserve the stack location where the exception was initially raised.

Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'CustomActions.UpdateCertificate(Session)' could contain the following variables 'CustomActions.GetCertThumbPrint(subjectName)', 'cmd.ExecuteScalar()', 'serializer.Deserialize(reader)'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'CustomActions.UpdateCertificate(Session)' could contain the following variables 'serializer.Deserialize(reader)', 'CustomActions.GetCertThumbPrint(subjectName)'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Rule.Name: Dispose objects before losing scope
Rule.Description: If a disposable object is not explicitly disposed before all references to it are out of scope, the object will be disposed at some indeterminate time when the garbage collector runs the finalizer of the object. Because an exceptional event might occur that will prevent the finalizer of the object from running, the object should be explicitly disposed instead.
Rule.Resolution: In method {0}, object {1} is not disposed along all exception paths. Call System.IDisposable.Dispose on object {1} before all references to it are out of scope.
In method {0}, call System.IDisposable.Dispose on object {1} before all references to it are out of scope.

Rule.Name: Rethrow to preserve stack details
Rule.Description: Use the IL rethrow instruction to preserve original stack details when re-raising a caught exception.
Rule.Resolution: {0} rethrows a caught exception and specifies it explicitly as an argument. Use 'throw' without an argument instead, in order to preserve the stack location where the exception was initially raised.

Rule.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Name: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Description: A SQL command string built from user input is vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. Microsoft SQL Server and other database servers support stored procedures and parameterized SQL queries, which reduce the risk of injection attacks.
Rule.Resolution: The query string passed to {0} in {1} could contain the following variables {2}. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.
